lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent: Let's explore how to manage state using the useState hook, focusing on advanced concepts like functional updates and batching state updates.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The simplest way to update state is by directly referencing its current value.

For example, we can use the existing state variable to calculate the new value and pass it to the updater function.

Make sure to pick setSmashPoints, followed by smashPoints, and finally + 1.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Functional updates ensure React always uses the latest state, even during rapid updates.

Instead of relying on the current state variable, we pass a function to the updater, which receives the previous state as an argument.

Make sure to pick (prevPoints), followed by =>, and finally prevPoints + 1.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Multiple setState calls inside the same event handler are batched together into a single re-render.

Batching state updates helps React optimize for a single re-render for efficiency.

Make sure to pick increaseScore followed by setScore and then setScore, increaseScore.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
You might want to use a state value as a getter, bypassing the setter. We can omit the setter if we never want to update a state variable.

Set a _ instead of the setter.

Make sure to pick _.

lessons.title: Lesson #4 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
While this is a valid approach, if you know the value won't change, consider using a plain constant instead of a state variable.

Set a _ instead of the setter.

Make sure to pick const followed by role and then =, "Admin", ;.

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use a function to set the initial state with useState. This is handy when calculating the initial state value.

In this case, we select a random character from the list of characters passed through the props.

Make sure to pick useState, followed by (, and finally ).

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use functional updates in state to ensure you're always using the latest state value.

Make sure to pick prevCount, followed by prevCount.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of the following is true when using functional updates in the useState hook?

They ensure that the most recent state is usedThey always cause multiple re-rendersThey do not allow accessing the previous stateThey are less efficient than direct updates

They ensure that the most recent state is used.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Call the function to batch multiple state updates to ensure efficient re-rendering.

Make sure to type updateStock.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the benefit of batching state updates in the same event handler?

It minimizes the number of re-rendersIt creates multiple render phasesIt always leads to performance issuesIt automatically logs state updates in the console

It minimizes the number of re-renders.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use useState with a function to calculate initial state values efficiently.

Make sure to pick (, followed by ), and finally =>.

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can you set the initial state using useState with a function?

Pass a function to useState that computes the initial valueDirectly assign a constant value inside the componentUse the setState functionUse a useMemo hook

Pass a function to useState that computes the initial value.

lessons.title: Lesson #14
lessons.interactiveContent:
Bypass the state setter if the value will not change, using a constant instead.

Make sure to type _.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why would you bypass using the state setter function entirely?

If a state variable is constant and doesn't changeTo increase render speed by removing stateState variables can't be used in functional componentsIt's a mistake and should be avoided

If a state variable is constant and doesn't change.
